terms.definition: A 3×3 strategic positioning grid for AI portfolios, mapping customer autonomy (Assist/Augment/Adapt) against execution autonomy (Static/Adaptive/Autonomous).
Three-tier capability maturity model: Assist (AI as tool), Augment (AI as collaborator), Adapt (AI as agent).
The third tier of AAA maturity where AI acts autonomously within defined boundaries, with humans providing oversight rather than direct control.
The first tier of AAA maturity where AI serves as a reactive tool, responding to human-initiated requests.
The second tier of AAA maturity where AI proactively suggests and collaborates, while humans retain decision authority.
The principle that internal capability (AAA tier) must match external position (9Q quadrant). Misalignment is the primary cause of AI initiative failure.
A weighted average score representing an organization's overall position on the human-AI collaboration spectrum, calculated from 9Q positions across the portfolio.
The vertical axis of the 9Q grid, describing how much decision-making authority the AI has in relation to the customer (Assist → Augment → Adapt).
The horizontal axis of the 9Q grid, describing how the AI's execution capability evolves (Static → Adaptive → Autonomous).
In the LLV framework, repeatable and predictable work with clear inputs, outputs, and consistent processes. High automation potential.
In the LLV framework, learning cycles that improve through iteration, feedback, and refinement. Augmentation sweet spot.
Lines, Loops & Vibes - a diagnostic framework categorizing organizational work into three types based on predictability, learning, and intuition.
Specific conditions that must be met before transitioning between AAA tiers. Includes technical, organizational, and trust gates.
The human ability to intervene and override AI decisions at any moment. Essential even at Adapt tier - enables trust rather than diminishes autonomy.
The pattern created when multiple AI initiatives are plotted on the 9Q grid. Reveals concentration, spread, direction, and gaps in AI strategy.
One of nine positions on the 9Q grid (Q1-Q9), each representing a distinct strategic position with specific characteristics and requirements.
The Curator position (Augment × Adaptive) where most leading organizations currently cluster. Represents equilibrium between capability and trust.
An organization's unique percentage distribution of work across Lines, Loops, and Vibes. Predicts where AI will create value.
Four approaches to work transformation with AI: Abandon (stop doing), Assist (AI helps), Augment (AI collaborates), Adapt (AI acts).
The accumulated trust that enables higher levels of AI autonomy. Built through consistent performance, transparency, and maintained override capability.
In the LLV framework, intuition-driven work involving pattern recognition, relationships, and creative leaps. Low automation potential - AI should inform, not replace.
